start.text: You're heading back to your personal quarters when a glaring red light along with a loud siren interrupt you. Sounds like your nap will have to be postponed once again. #8t4wl9

start2.text: Back to the control center, you see that the alarm going off is the earthquake one. #6cu6ji

small_earthquake.text: Thankfully, it seems the amplitude of it is relatively limited, and that the epicenter is away from any region hosting your species. The effects on the biosphere at large will be small, although probably long-lasting. #b7cxqa

install_better_seismometers_choice.text: Perhaps it's a good idea to install better seismometers? #c5hwlk

choices.text: “And get even more alarms about events that small? I'd rather be able to nap in peace, thank you very much.” #wns6e3
“Better safe than sorry - that's always been my motto.” #s69qzr
“There are more urgent matters that also need what we'd spend. The risk isn't that high. I think.” #sqwskl

big_earthquake2.text: The effects on your species and even the ecosystem overall are hard to estimate. #olhlxk

earthquake_reports.text: Once the earthquake is finished, you begin to get reports left and right. Most are either good news about groups of your species members being very disoriented but fine, or news so bad that it's too late to do anything. #viwzfw

report_catches_attention.text: One report catches your attention though: #5mdho6

report_about_stuck_specimens.text: It's about a pack of your species members stuck below a pile of rocks. You could actually help improve the situation here. #wwwdmw

choices.text: “Let natural selection do its job here. The species will do better without specimens idiotic enough to get themselves into that kind of situation.” #fukm7f
“Let's go right now! Every minute counts!” #hlux9j
“We can't risk focusing our help and attention to a single pack like that in these dire times. What if something happens at the global level?” #1pyowv

go_help_stuck_specimens_too_late.text: You arrive at the site but it seems like it's too late. You're barely able to rescue a couple specimens. #ie3xj7

scavengers_come.text: As if trying to recover from the earthquake direct consequences wasn't hard enough as it is, scavengers have been spotted near the site where you failed to rescue specimens buried under rocks after the earthquake. They're heavily disrupting the food chain in the area - it will take a while to retrieve a balanced a balance environment again. #p23m00

go_help_stuck_specimens_in_time.text: You arrive at the site and while the task of rescuing the specimens proves to be very hard, you manage to save each and every one of them. #yes8c0

choices.text: “That will be one of my most prized memories! We did something great today!” #oo56hn
“What we did today, that's a story worth sharing. Call journalists, we can sell it!” #f9isxa

report_about_destroyed_shelters.text: It's about a pack of your species members: the primitive shelters they had built have collapsed and can't protect them anymore. You could actually help improve the situation here. #c49c8p

destroyed_shelters_choice.text: When you finally get to the area, you and your team sedate the disoriented specimens and come up with three possible solutions: #3nkhip

choices.text: Try to repair the collapsed shelters in a way to minimize your influence #wmffix
Build sturdy shelters from scratch with good materials, then paint and cover them with some remains of the collapsed shelters to make it less obvious #hg5kvl
Move the specimens to a new, more welcoming region, so they won't need shelters as much #06o1so

move_specimens.text: The operation takes a while to complete, but the trip goes remarkably well. #48wk3e

move_successful.text: Later observations show the specimens have gotten well adapted to their new home. The impact on the ecosystem around them will be noticeable but ultimately limited. #q2ldvy

move_fail.text: Later observations show the specimens have some trouble adapting to their new home though. They've been disrupting the ecosystem around them quite a bit. #scrhgr

shelters_completed.text: Just as you finish taking care of the last shelter, some of the specimens begin to show signs of waking up. #0y3xer

shelters_successful.text: Later observations show the specimens really like their new shelters. #r463u1

shelters_fail.text: Later observations show the specimens dislike their new shelters and end up avoiding them altogether. One pile of big cardboard boxes you've forgotten near the area seems to have gotten really popular though. #4nxxw4

nothing_can_be_done.text: There's nothing significant you can do, but wait and see how the situation sorts itself out. #ccg7uh

mountain_flattened.text: It's been a while since the earthquake struck, but you still get some reports now and then about consequences of it, as can be expected from a big event like that. One day, you read one mentioning how the earthquake managed to level one small mountain. It proves how powerful the earthquake was, but more interestingly, it opens a new area for your species, who was so far unable to go over the mountain. #b2gedj

choices.text: “We should encourage them to go explore that new territory! Let's use some baits to lure them there over time.” #l70huj
“They'll figure out there's a new area now open for them soon enough, on their own. No need to force what can happen organically.” #at7omk

create_trails_success.text: Your efforts are fruitful - a lot of specimens follow the trails you've created. #5wm24k

big_migration_successful.text: And it's good news, since they they seem to really enjoy their new home - food is plentiful and there's no one higher on the food chain than them there. #j51h2j

big_migration_fail.text: You soon realize what an error that was, when most of your specimens are caught by apex predators they aren't used to fight off, as the mountain used to protect your species from them. #jxxiz1

create_trails_fail.text: Your efforts aren't really paying off. Only a few specimens follow the trails you've created. #c1iy9e

no_trails.text: Your non-intervention leads to only a few, bold specimens to go explore the newly accessible land. #htaq7s

small_migration_successful.text: It's too bad, since they seem to really enjoy their new home - food is plentiful and there's no one higher on the food chain than them there. #dbnx57

small_migration_fail.text: It's probably for the best though - your species looks awfully inadapted to the fauna there, and very few specimens escape the apex predators of the area. #ql5ioa
